newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Belarus union pact's fate, text still unclear.
newsitem.headline: Belarus union pact's fate, text still unclear.

text.p: Russian newspapers on Tuesday questioned the logic of a proposed union between Russia and Belarus and some said the document on the deal had been hurriedly prepared without adequate consulations.

"They are deciding the fate of Russia behind the backs of the people," the liberal daily newspaper Izvestia said in its lead article. "Was it agreement or conspiracy prepared in the corridors of power?"
Other newspapers said Russian President Boris Yeltsin, who is due to sign a document on the Union with his Belarussian counterpart Alexander Lukashenko on Wednesday, was still working out what to do.

"Hours before the meeting with Alexander Lukashenko, Russian President Boris Yeltsin has not made a final decision because the consequences mean both clear benefits for Russia and undisputable losses," Komsomolskaya Pravda said.

The draft document, to be signed exactly a year after an outline agreement between the two leaders, says the two former Soviet republics would remain independent but would coordinate their foreign, economic and military policies closely.

"On April 3 Russians will wake up in the same country where they went to bed," said a headline in the Sevodnya newspaper. The next line read: "if only because not a single serious treaty has been fulfilled in the Commonweath of Independent States."
The newspaper recalled last year's signing of a deal on a Russia-Belarus commonwealth.
"Nobody has ever referred to this treaty since then... It also was about synchronising reforms in two countries, creating conditions to introduce a single currency and foreign policy coordination."
Russia, a nuclear state of nearly 150 million people, has been working a "community" with its less wealthy western neighbour of 10 million under a deal signed by the two leaders on April 2 last year.
But few details have been worked out and many questions remain unanswered.

"The draft treaty looks more like a declaration of intentions rather than a treaty to create a new state," said Nezavisimaya Gazeta, noting that it was not clear how powers would be divided between the two states.
Communist-oriented Sovietskaya Rossiya quoted Aman Tuleyev, Russia's Minister for Co-operation with the Commonwealth of Independent States, in an article headlined "Who is attacking Our Union".
Tuleyev, himself a communist, said Russia would benefit economically and politically from union with Belarus.
"It looks like (the opponents) are putting pressure on the president (Boris Yeltsin), who decided to take this step against the wishes of the United States," the newspaper said.
Russia's embrace of Belarus comes at a time of increasing international isolation for Minsk, which has cracked down on political dissent, and where the authorities last week expelled a U.S. diplomat.
